body.p: Sixteenth vice president and Seventeenth president of the United States. Member of the Democratic Party. Married to Eliza McCardle in 1827. Father of Martha Johnson Patterson, Charles Johnson, Mary Johnson Stover, Robert Johnson, and Andrew Johnson, Jr. No formal education, apprenticed to a tailor. Worked as a tailor in North Carolina, South Carolina, Alabama, and Greenville, Tennessee. Elected as alderman of Greeneville, Tennessee, in 1829, and mayor of Greeneville in 1834. Represented Greene County, Tennessee and Washington County, Tennessee in the House of Representatives of the State of Tennessee from 1835 to 1837 and 1839 to 1841. Served as a Democratic presidential elector in 1840. Served as senator in the Senate of the state of Tennessee from 1841 to 1843. Represented the 1st District of Tennessee in the United States House of Representatives from 1843 to 1853. Served as governor of Tennessee from 1853 to 1857. Served as a senator from Tennessee in the United States Senate from 1857 to 1862. Served as military governor of Tennessee, with the rank of brigadier general, from 1862 to 1865. Elected as vice president of the United States on the National Union Party ticket on November 8, 1864. Elevated to president of the United States on April 15, 1865, following the assassination of Abraham Lincoln, and served until March 4, 1869.
